Sims and Stone (2016) 28 August, state that: The free trade negotiations between the European Union and the United States have failed, but “nobody is really admitting it”, Germany's Vice-Chancellor Sigmar Gabriel has said. 
Talks over the so-called Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, also known as TTIP, have made little progress in recent years.
The 14th round of negotiations between American and EU officials took place in Brussels in July. It was the third round in six months.
At the time, the talks were thought to be in trouble after a number of leading European politicians expressed concern about TTIP’s effects and the US’s reluctance to accept changes to the proposed deal.
In May, cracks emerged when France threatened to block the deal.
President Hollande said he would "never accept" the deal in its current guise because of the rules it enforces on France and the rest of Europe – particularly in relation to farming and culture – claiming they are too friendly to US businesses.
“We will never accept questioning essential principles for our agriculture, our culture and for the reciprocity of access to public [procurement] markets,” Mr Hollande is reported as saying at a meeting of left-wing politicians in Paris. “At this stage [of the talks] France says, ‘No'.”
Speaking on Sunday, Mr Gabriel, who is also Germany’s Economy Minister, said: “In my opinion, the negotiations with the United States have de facto failed, even though nobody is really admitting it." (para. 1-8). Sims, A. & Stone, J. (2016) TTIP has failed – but no one is admitting it, says German Vice-Chancellor Sigmar Gabriel. The Independent. World. Europe. Retrieved from

RT News (2016) states that: Thousands of protesters took to the streets of Paris and Warsaw, urging their governments to reject the TTIP and CETA free-trade agreements with the US and Canada. 
Some 7,000 people demonstrated in the Polish capital of Warsaw on Saturday, RIA Novosti reported.
Expressing disapproval of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) with the US and the strikingly similar Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) deal with Canada, protesters marched in central Warsaw near the country's Agriculture Ministry building and prime minister's offices.
In France, collectively, over 40,000 people took to the streets in more than 30 cities, according to TASS. The largest protest was organized in Paris, with people demanding the French government follow their neighbors in Belgium, where lawmakers from a French-speaking region of Wallonia recently voted against the CETA deal.
While Paris suspended talks with Washington over TTIP, the CETA agreement might still get the green light in France, with Prime Minister Manuel Valls having said the deal is "legally balanced." EU ministers supporting the agreement with Canada argue that it is favorable for Europe, as it would create new jobs, improve trade and free the bloc of almost all tariffs and customs duties (para. 1-5). Negotiations were launched in June 2013 between the US the 28-country EU. This compares to negotiations on the EU-Canadian CETA deal negotiations beginning in 2009. Other EU trade deals, even those with much smaller countries without federal systems have similarly taken much more than 3 years on average. The political side of things looks much more difficult. It looks like there are a number of negotiating disagreements over investor settlement, privacy issues and food standards. A new American President is soon to come in, on the back of a campaign that has been anti-free trade on both sides and the EU would not want a new deal in any case with uncertainties hanging over the result. As the UK leaves the EU, the deal is put in further peril, without the UK's wholehearted support. Added to this, is widespread opposition across Europe, including from the German vice-Chancellor who has proclaimed TTIP dead in all but name. Even in the most optimistic scenario, it is just not feasible for negotiations to be completed in the current political climate. I would say on the timing alone, there is a 15% chance. Add in the political complications, and you reach a figure a quarter of that at 4%.

Disregarding the politics of the agreement for a moment, completing the negotiations by 1 January 2017 would be a speed record for a trade agreement like the TTIP. The first round of negotiations took place in July 2013, barely 3.5 years before the deadline of the question. For comparison: CETA took 5 years and the TPP took 7 years to negotiate. Both are of comparable complexity and involve some of the same partners. TTIP is in fact the youngest of all negotiations listed as "ongoing" on this list (http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_MEMO-13-734_en.htm). To me this indicates that even if TTIP were a completely de-politicized and average trade agreement, finalizing negotiations within 3.5 years would be extremely unlikely. It shouldn't come as a surprise therefore that as of April 2016, only four of the 25+ negotiation sectors were in an "advanced stage of consolidation" with five sectors still without even concrete proposals by the two parties (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transatlantic_Trade_and_Investment_Partnership#Negotiation_progress). On the other hand, there is considerable institutional pressure to conclude the negotiations as soon as possible, so the probability of an all-out effort to finish the negotiations by the end of 2016 is not 0. It should also be noted that the negotiation teams work mostly independent of the politicians that are declaring TTIP dead nowadays. These are career bureaucrats who have a clear mandate to conduct negotiations along certain lines. If they can find common ground, they will. The politics impact primarily the question of ratification, not negotiation. The exception to this rule are questions that were obscure only a few years ago and are now subject to intense public scrutiny, like the investor protection measures (arbitration courts, etc). It is possible that the E.U. has changed its negotiation position on some of these issues with an eye on getting the treaty ratified, which will have complicated the negotiations. Based on these assumptions alone I would give "yes" a probability of 15%. Based on news that France has called for an end of the negotiations (which would undermine the mandate of the negotiators) I will lower this forecast to 5% and with the option to lower it further depending how this plays out over the coming weeks. The French position is likely a campaign play, not politics of conviction, but France is an important country in the E.U. and if the government has decided that the negotiations should go away at least for the duration of the presidential campaign, it will set the process back for at least six months.

COMMENT:  I do not think that this article gives sufficient weight to the anti-trade agreement sentiment in the US.  Obama wants TTIP, but neither Clinton nor Trump, nor the members of their respective parties do. The structure of this question is the problem. There seems almost no chance that any of the current area trade deals involving the USA or the EU will be ratified anytime soon because in the public mind negotiated trade deals equate to giving jobs to foreigners and/or setting up arbitration systems that give away sovereignty. So the average voter is convinced that a trade deal is a "bad thing". (What the average voter wants is a gun boat sent to the foreign country to force them to give us a sweet deal, as we did things in the 19th Century).   
However the question is will negotiations  be completed. Negotiations could be completed with an agreement that is likely to be ratified, Negotiations could be completed with an agreement that is unlikely to be ratified. Negotiations could be completed with no agreement at all.  With several big elections coming up in the next 15 months or so (US, French, German etc.) it is unknown which politicians would be in office when any TTIP agreement came up for ratification. Therefore completing negotiations in 2016 seems pointless because that would mean attempting to ratify an agreement that had been made under a different administration (certainly in the US and almost certainly in France). From exposure to the Brexit campaign, it seems that the EU is best understood, from a trade zone perspective, as primarily a PROTECTION zone. It's primary purpose is to preserve EU markets for inefficient legacy EU producers. Reduction of cost of imported goods or expansion of foreign trade are secondary considerations. With this is mind, and given that there is expected to be some pressure for a number of countries to leave the EU, the EU could, if they had some sort of deal in place, use such an agreement as a bargaining chip to protect various European markets, and hence retain the loyalties of certain EU legacy manufacturers, who would in turn lobby their governments to stay within the union. In short, Brexit aside, it's possibly a way to garner loyalty from other countries on the fence over leaving; hence some increased urgency to get it completed. More trinkets, baubles, and regulatory over-specification so as to write-out competition, in lieu of democratic transactional freedom; but it's been successful before.

Will TTIP require ratification by national parliaments?
https://global.handelsblatt.com/edition/452/ressort/politics/article/fighting-over-the-last-word-on-ttip While at first glance the topic of "ratification" may seem independent of "completion," nothing could be further from the truth. Surprisingly, the exact process for ratification (which we can define as whatever is required to bring a completed agreement into full force) appears to be presently undecided! If we assume that a process which would require a vote of acceptance in each national parliament is required, we could, I believe, also assume that the terms of the TTIP would need to be more "palatable." If consent by national parliaments is not required, we can assume, I believe, that the negotiators will hold out for the most pro-investor interests possible, being assured that the EU will, even with highly contentious sovereignty-busting, socially distasteful terms, swallow it (whatever it is) whole. I've maintained my forecast on the basis that a "less ambitious" agreement, one that jettisons the contentious flotsam (e.g., the investor-state dispute mechanism), can be achieved in the relevant time period, but not a "more ambitious" agreement. With consent of national parliaments eliminated, there is little to restrain the "negotiators" from just holding out indefinitely. Why give up an opportunity to achieve "ambitious" permanent change? [The idea being that whatever is agreed, is done; else it would not be agreed in the first place.] (-1) As an aside, that such an issue is undecided, and moreover lacks a clear and specific procedure, speaks tons about how disorganized the entire EU program is.

June 7th marked the creation of the Transatlantic Financial Regulatory Coherence Coalition.
The coalition hopes to place regulatory coherence and market access for US and EU financial services companies in the TTIP agreement.  The coalition supports inclusion while the US Treasury Dept and Pres Obama are currently against.   Negotiations are intensifying:
The next formal round of TTIP negotiations is scheduled to occur in Europe during July, though intercessional meetings are occurring with increasing frequency. Coalition objectives:
From: http://www.bna.com/coalition-pushes-ttip-n57982073862/
"This is a very important time. And we think this issue is as vitally important as we did in 2013,” when TTIP negotiations began, Matheson said. “So we thought it would be useful to bring ourselves together in a slightly more formal way to be in a position to more efficiently and effectively have that discussion,” he said.
To overcome existing impediments to transboundary financial activity, the coalition will push for TTIP language to ensure early-stage discussions on policy matters, facilitate discussion concerning future policymaking and regulatory developments and generally advocate for greater accountability and transparency.
“As negotiations move into the next critical stage, we felt it important to pool our resources through this Coalition to educate on the benefits of a comprehensive approach to financial services within TTIP,” Matthew Ekberg, Institute of International Finance senior policy advisor for regulatory affairs, said in a June 7 e-mail sent to Bloomberg BNA.
“All aspects of the negotiations are still in discussion and regulatory coherence and market access are critical for a complete agreement. As such, we believe the time is right to continue actively engaging policy makers on both sides of the Atlantic on these important issues,” Ekberg, whose organization is a coalition member, said in his statement.

Zero is a very risky forecast; backing off by just 3% saves a lot of Brier points if one's wrong because the penalty is 3x the reward. (The Brier score for perfectly correct is .000, and for 50% is .500, so each % away from 50% on the correct side of 50% reduces your Brier score by .010.   Actually, the graph of Brier score to forecast % is not a straight line from perfectly right to 50%, it's a parabolic curve, but it helps me to think in these terms.)    However, the Brier points for perfectly wrong is 2.000, so each % away from 50% on the wrong side of 50% costs you .030 Brier points.  Again,  the graph of Brier score to forecast % is not a straight line from 50-100% wrong, it's a parabolic curve, but it helps me to think in these terms.) I see plenty of leaders and potential leaders who are more interested in blaming all the ills of the world on foreigners in general and free-trade in particular. The leaders who would be most sympathetic to TTIP are struggling with other "liberal" policies that are upsetting voters and do not want another fight. Obama is getting to the end of his presidency and has plenty of unfinished issues to work on before he goes, without wanted to add another. All the front runners for being the next president appear to want more protection not more free trade.

I feel obliged to write from an European perspective as most GJOpen users are American citizens. I would like to bring in some other argument to the table. This topic, at least on the German street boils down to one issue: chlorinated chicken! http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2014-08-08/why-chlorine-chicken-from-america-inspires-dread-in-europe The idea of maximum efficiency (profits) at all costs to public health, the environment and possibly even quality of lives is uniformly symbolized by this chlorinated chicken issue. Without divulging too deep, the general idea of TTIP is that the EU must lower its standard to accommodate corporate interests from the US. If this is true to beside the point… To the French perspective, it is all about labor. Pay, vacations and employee benefits. Summed up: the 35 hour work week. There is a fear that TTIP will lower their income and may cause major reforms to remain competitive. All summed up here, although with a few more points: https://global.handelsblatt.com/edition/387/ressort/politics/article/france-non-to-watered-down-trade-treaty To the idea that it is a legacy of Obama is wrong. Initial discussions were held in 1995, starting with the TAFTA and later in 2007 with TEC. The TTIP is merely the next “try” to find an agreement. For the agreement to work from a European perspective, at least symbolically, one major law must be reversed or annulled: the “Buy American Act”. Given the election season, I personally doubt this will happen in 2016. Lastly, here is a leaked website on the negotiations. It is claimed that end of 2016 is very unlikely: https://correctiv.org/en/investigations/ttip/blog/2015/04/21/tricky-schedule/ Thus, the new question should be will TTIP or a “light-version” be agreed upon by 2020?

"European Commissioner for Trade Cecilia Malmström . . . hopes to reach a compromise by the end of 2016, before President Barack Obama’s term ends in January 2017, and U.S. officials say they share the same goal. "Here are five potential sticking points: "1. Regulatory cooperation . . .  harmonizing regulatory standards. . . Critics. . . . are concerned that such an alignment “bears the risk of introducing U.S. regulatory standards that could lower our level of consumer protection,” . . . The TTIP agreement seems to be having difficulty with those aspects where trade interfaces politics. One such area is the concept of a "Regulatory Cooperating Body." Another, no less contentious but far more prominent at the moment, is that of "investment protection." It seems there are basically three positions here:
1) The American position: Enhance the existing Investor-State Dispute Settlement (ISDS) framework which would provide maximum supra-sovereignty to foreign corporations via specialized commercial arbitration panels.
2) The EU position: Replace the ISDS framework with a new Investment Court System (ICS). This position is identical to the American position in terms of providing maximum supra-sovereignty to foreign corporations, except it accomplishes this with a body of professional judges and provides states the right of appeal. The path from the EU position to desired eventual world investment court via the UN is more straightforward.
3) The Juncker position. This would drop the idea of privileged investment protection for foreign corporations from the TTIP altogether, and place foreign corporations on the same standing as domestic corporations. This position broke an earlier block which allowed the TTIP to move forward, but was quickly abandoned once the negotiation process gained full steam. The concept of "investment protection" completely turns around the classic challenge of "foreign investment country risk." Hitherto, if you chose to invest in the foreign country Peanutland, for example, your investment was subject to the whims of whatever the government of Peanutland might do. Anything from labor, process, or market regulation to outright confiscation of the entire investment was possible, without recourse (unless, of course, you could get your government to send in your military or the like). It seems investors desire to reduce these "country risks" to zero, which, from a portfolio perspective, would be a very nice boost to the return on capital (although they never fully bore the costs of sending in the military anyway). The pro argument is that "investment protection" would boost local economies because without such protection local economies would suffer, since potential investors would not invest in them. I consider the current flap to be no more than posturing around one of these three positions, and believe the issue will be resolved in this period.  That some positions may have been turned "almost into a religion,” however, obviously does add some uncertainty. (-5) [Edit: Positions #1 and #2 are favored heavily by the financial interests. The general public overwhelmingly favors position #3. (The number of responses to an EC request for public comment exceeded 100,000; a crazy large number for something so obscure as a trade agreement.) Positions #1 and #2 are a backdoor grab of nation-state sovereignty (Corporation XYZ could sue Peanutland for banning ingredient ABC or restricting their product to adults over 21, or whatever.) The American financial lobby want the benefit without the overhead of the EU system. The EU financial lobby wants the benefit and the overhead because it fits into their vision of global regulation where they set the standards. An unsurprising outcome of positions #1 or #2 will be the change in domicile of ALL corporations to a jurisdiction outside where they do business to obtain the asymmetric benefits of being a foreign corporation. This upheaval would soon be followed with the disarray of local corporate law, contracting, and governance. (I am surprised the State of Delaware isn't objecting to these positions more vociferously.) I don't expect that sober decisions in the best interest of humanity will be made, but I do expect the roadblock to be eliminated.]

That will be challenging, given the technical complexity and the vigorous opposition. It would then have to be approved by the European Parliament and European Trade Ministers. The Ministers usually vote on trade by what is called qualified majority though unanimity might be required - that is both a legal question and a matter of political judgement.
Depending on the legal nature of the final agreement it might also need to be approved by all the EU member states, and Commissioner Malmström has said that is likely to be necessary. So there is plenty of scope for delays.
And it will need approval by the US Congress. President Obama is struggling unsuccessfully so far - to get Congress to give him what is called Trade Promotion Authority which would make US ratification less difficult. http://www.bbc.com/news/business-32691589

http://www.bna.com/us-eu-look-n57982065951/ Jan. 6 — " . . .TTIP negotiations are expected to kick into high gear in 2016, with both sides doubling down on trying to finish talks during the last year of the Obama administration and rejecting the concept of a “TTIP light,” which officials said would be hard to sell to Congress and the European Parliament.
. . . 
"EU Ambassador to the U.S. David O'Sullivan said that, if all goes well, TTIP could be concluded sometime in 2016 but probably would not take effect until 2018. "The two sides are still far from the point of reaching the “endgame” of negotiations, where sensitive political issues are addressed, one source said. The endgame is only possible once the middle-game is over, the source said, pointing to the need for clear instructions from U.S. Trade Representative Michael Froman and European Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmstroem by mid-2016 on how to focus on the most politically challenging issues. "Endgame issues include geographical indications, certain agricultural tariffs and sensitivities on government procurement and financial services. The EU will continue to ask for “exceptions in agriculture — beef, sugar, poultry and pork,” Malmstroem said. The U.S. is expected to push back on carve-outs for agricultural products. Food safety issues also will be difficult to resolve. U.S. and EU officials will convene a high-level working group in early 2016 to discuss geographical indications. "The next TTIP round is expected to take place the week of Feb. 22 in Brussels. Having credible initial offers on procurement would be an important advance in the talks, one source told Bloomberg BNA. The two sides also need to advance consolidated texts and proposals in the areas where they have not yet done so, sources told Bloomberg BNA. Discussions on regulatory cooperation in specific sectors — pharmaceuticals, medical devices, cosmetics, textiles, cars, information and communication technology, engineering, chemicals and pesticides—will require clear and concrete ideas about what the outcome will be in specific sectors, the source said, commenting that this would be an important milestone to reach in the February talks. " . . .  O'Sullivan was bullish on the possibility of reaching the middle-game in February, meaning that all issues are up for discussion and negotiation and there is an idea of what the final deal will look like.  “The objective is to get to the point where we have mapped the full scope of the agreement and all issues are on the table,” he told Bloomberg BNA.  The endgame issue will be mapped out in less detail than areas where agreement can be reached sooner, O'Sullivan added. "An important part of the middle-game discussions would be a credible offer from the U.S. side on government procurement, he said. “We expect to see an ambitious and meaningful offer as was discussed in the high-level working group when we were preparing these negotiations,” O'Sullivan said. This means an offer that significantly improves European access to the U.S. procurement market, which O'Sullivan said is currently subject to restrictions at both the federal and subfederal level. "Tim Bennett, director general and chief executive officer of the Transatlantic Business Council, told Bloomberg BNA that wrapping up TTIP was doable by late 2016. Waiting until 2017 to close negotiations could close the window of opportunity, he said.  Bennett expressed “strong skepticism” that TTIP talks could be restarted once the current U.S. administration leaves, as 2017 will be focused on putting a new Cabinet in place. Also, Germany and France—key TTIP countries—will hold elections in 2017. For these reasons, it will be difficult to get back to the negotiating table in 2017, he said. The political difficulty increases on the European side as additional time elapses, he said. "Congressional ratification of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) would “clear the deck” for earlier consideration of the TTIP, one source said. If the TPP is ratified by Congress in 2016, this would make it easier to get into the endgame of negotiations on TTIP, the source said. "O'Sullivan said there is no direct relationship between the TTIP and the completed Trans-Pacific Partnership. If the TPP is approved in 2016, that “would certainly add momentum,” O'Sullivan said. If the TPP takes longer, the EU will still push for the conclusion of TTIP negotiations with the Obama administration. The EU is currently negotiating with a number of TPP partners, he said, noting that countries are capable of negotiating multiple agreements simultaneously. "In Bennett's view, congressional review and consideration of the TPP will not interfere with the TTIP negotiating process. Some of the TPP provisions could provide guidance in the TTIP, Bennett said, citing TPP provisions on intellectual property, state-owned enterprises and e-commerce.
. .. .
"The European Commission has proposed reforming the investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS) system by establishing an appeal mechanism and an international court. The ISDS proposal has been criticized in the U.S. by business associations and on both continents by nongovernmental organizations claiming that it does not go far enough. U.S. and EU negotiators will engage in substantive discussions on the new EU proposal in February. The ISDS mechanism allows companies to seek compensation from foreign governments on the basis of commitments in the trade agreement through international tribunals. "The Commission proposal will cause pushback in some areas, such as the international court, but issues such as increased transparency, third-party participation and rules to avoid conflicts for arbitrators have already been worked through by the U.S. in its model bilateral investment treaty review, Bennett told Bloomberg BNA. ISDS provisions can be successfully negotiated, Bennett said, speculating that ISDS would not be an endgame issue. "The U.S. will have to digest and react to the EU proposal, O'Sullivan said. Some parts will be harder to accept than others, but the public consultation process in Europe has resulted in a situation where the EU is now willing to negotiate an ISDS clause, he said. The TPP contains certain “evolutions” on the ISDS clause, he said. With constructive discussion on both sides, O'Sullivan voiced confidence that the parties could craft an ISDS clause that would be acceptable to both sides. An acceptable outcome on the ISDS issue will be a very important criterion when the TTIP is judged by constituencies in Europe and the European Parliament, O'Sullivan said. "Building on the tariff offers, delving into the investment proposal, moving forward on regulatory cooperation and starting to build toward final agreement, and clarifying where Froman and Malmstroem need to step in and give guidance will be important mileposts for the next round, Bennett said. For the difficult political issues, the EU needs to get approval from the EU Council representing the 28 member states, Bennett said. That additional step is needed for approval on the EU side. " . . .  One issue that should be addressed is harmonizing de minimis thresholds relating to the import of small, low-value consignments into the European Union. The EU de minimis is less than $200. “It's a tough issue that we've been trying to find a solution for,” Laney said.  The pending Trade Facilitation and Trade Enforcement Act of 2015 would raise the current $200 de minimis threshold in the U.S. to $800. “We are seeking a Customs de minimis that protects importers from the imposition of ‘all' taxes and duties at the border, including [value added taxes (VAT)]. There have been proposals by some for a de minimis that provides no ‘customs' taxes and duties; however, VAT would be applied,” Laney told Bloomberg BNA. "Another key issue relates to a single window for trade data, Laney said. While the U.S. is moving quickly, the EU has not progressed as fast. Laney said trying to ensure that the EU moves in that direction is critical. He acknowledged that it is unclear whether the TTIP would include specific text in this area. Better aligning the EU's Authorized Economic Operator (AEO) program with U.S. Customs and Border Protection's Customs and Trade Partnership would enhance the security capacity of both regions. Laney said the AEO program should be strengthened.

TIPP negotiations started in the beginning of 2013, so making it through 2016 would mean four years. The only vaguely comparable situation is the US-CAFTA-DR treaty, which took only a year to negotiate. However, there was no central CAFTA representative. All in all, it seems that US has never achieved a treaty of such importance. On the other side, there is nothing on this scale, but EU has negotiated a few other treaties with other states:
+ With South Korea, EU negotiated from 2007 through 2009 (although it built on two previous treaties).
+ With Colombia and Peru, it took from 2007 through 2010.
- With Canada, EU needed from 2009 to 2014 (and now looks to be renegotiated)
- With Ukraine, EU negotiated between 2008 and 2012.
- With Japan, EU started negotiations in 2013, and failed to make the 2015 "deadline".
- With India, EU has negotiated since 2007 (now suspended).
- With Turkey, EU has negotiated since the dawn of times.
It took 4 years or less only with SK, Colombia, and Peru. US seems more similar to India, open to increase exports, but protective of its internal market, so again it seems like 4 years will be insufficient. Revise down.

I think what we are seeing here is push-back.  An obvious path of least resistance for TTIP negotiations is to mirror terms already agreed to in TPP. There are provisions in the TPP that McConnell's (R-Tobacco) and Hatch's (R-Pharma) sponsors don't like. They signal that y'all can negotiate all you like, we can't stop you, but we'll stop ratification. (McConnell can do that all by himself so long as he holds the position of Majority Leader.) Arrayed against that is a goodly portion of the rest of American industry, notably Ag and Auto, who are actually at the negotiating table, are reasonably happy with TPP and therefore, presumably, hopeful to see similar terms in TTIP. McConnell and Hatch have effectively signaled that they are putting down markers so that tobacco and pharma have a few more chips to play at the table and see if they can sweeten the deal.

COMMENT:  The more parties there are in a negotiation, the more difficult it is to arrive at a consensus.  This is a gigantic deal. Monumental issues remain to be ironed out.

In favor:
Obama wants to finish negotiations before his term is over. Part of his legacy.
After the most recent round of negotiations in October, both sides said they hoped to complete the negotiations in 2016. Probably hot air, but it was a stated commitment. Against:
US election timing
EU politics and general spread of anti-EU sentiment in Europe.
Demands by several EU parties to have a greater say before agreement reached (not just ratification), which could lead to delays.
Negotiations usually take longer than expected.  I lean against, but there are a lot of uncertainties that make me want to hedge.

* There are two key parts to this question: will TTIP happen (85%)? Will TTIP happen by Jan 2017 (25%)? morningtrade@politico.com "Today, Europe Brief explores one of the biggest hurdles to a TTIP agreement - opposition from the EU agriculture lobby . . . 
U.S. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack made headlines in Brussels earlier this week when he said that some of the biggest roadblocks to a TTIP deal will come in the agriculture sector - including EU opposition to increased imports of U.S. beef.  ". . .  John Brook, the European regional director of the U.S. Meat Export Federation . .  . [said]  that he's not optimistic about the prospects for a TTIP deal, largely because of opposition from the European opposition agriculture sector. "QUOTE OF NOTE: "Try and find me someone here in agriculture, first of all, who wants TTIP and believes in it," Brook told Europe Brief. "The resistance to TTIP in European agriculture sector is huge. It's certainly protectionist." 'THE BACKDROP: European concerns about the U.S. farm and food industry's standards, including the use of GMOs, hormone-fed cattle and chlorine-washed poultry, are well-documented and remain a point of contention for U.S. meat exporters. "I've never met a European who has been to the U.S. and said they didn't dare eat anything because of the hormones," Brook maintains. "They go to the steakhouse and say it was fantastic." " You talk to anyone in the poultry sector, they're still going to say U.S. poultry is done more cheaply than European poultry because of access to GMO feed," says Brook. "The Europeans will also say that [Americans] don't have the same hygiene standards because you rinse chicken in chlorine, and we don't permit that. We do permit people to go into public swimming pools where there is chlorine, but we don't permit the chickens to go into swimming pools." "BY THE NUMBERS: EU farm interests worry that TTIP could bring down the mix of tariff barriers, quotas and sanitary regulations that limit imports of U.S. beef to Europe. A longstanding ban on hormone-fed beef imports imposed by the European Union means that U.S. beef being shipped to the European Union has to be certified as hormone-free, and is produced specifically for the European Union in a non-hormone treated cattle program. The European Union also has a 48,000-ton quota for imported meat allowed to enter the continent at zero percent tariff. Right now, the United States' share of that quota is 40 percent, while Australia and Uruguay control the other 60 percent. In total, the restrictions mean that the U.S. exports a smaller amount of beef to Europe than it might otherwise send. The United States currently exports about 17,000 tons or $250 million worth of beef a year to the European Union per year, says Brook. "ONE OUTLIER: BIG YOGURT. Brooks notes that the European dairy industry has been one of the few supporters of TTIP in the EU agriculture sector. Brook says that's because of the growing market for high-end dairy products like Greek yogurt. "THE BOTTOM LINE: It's a catch-22 of sorts: Europeans are reluctant to include agriculture in the TTIP deal, but Brook's bosses in Washington won't do the deal without it. "The United States says they won't do it without agriculture. Those are the people I work for," said Brook. "So even if the Agriculture Committee [in the Senate] is three percent of the population, they still say they can have a majority that would block the ratification of a TTIP if it doesn't include agriculture." "VILSACK'S TAKE: That's essentially what Vilsack had to say earlier this week, when he noted that GMOs, beef and U.S. opposition to EU origin protection designations were key sticking points. "The agricultural interests in the United States, by themselves, are not politically powerful enough to get an agreement passed, but they are certainly powerful enough to stop agreement that's been negotiated," Vilsack said: http://reut.rs/1XJV8u3 ". . .  U.S. Trade Representative Michael Froman has made it clear that the U.S. government isn't keen on working out a separate free trade agreement with the U.K. if the country were to leave the European Union. . . . "The U.S. and the European Union hope to complete the TTIP deal before President Barack Obama leaves office in 14 months, joining together the world's two largest economies, covering more than $35 trillion in economic output, or roughly 46 percent of the world total. But one looming complication of the deal is that many Britons want out of their four-decade-old membership in the EU ... They want the country to take back full control of its borders and reduce the number of other Europeans crossing the English Channel to find work and believe the U.K. could do better striking trade deals on its own." http://politico.pro/1NJ4VAZ

It might be a good time to consult the heralded Oxford dictionary for the definition of fait accompli, viz., "A thing that has already happened or been decided before those affected hear about it, leaving them with no option but to accept." Seems appropriate, and very close. I'd say that there's also always an option to reject as well, but this is usually made difficult based on so-called practicalities. It is my personal opinion that the TTIP should be rejected on the principle that is the product of a flawed developmental framework, regardless of its merits (if any). This is my first forecast on this question, and for the moment I am quite sceptical that US and EU negotiators will be able to conclude all chapters before 2017. I see a lack of political support in important EU countries such as Germany (who might push for renegotiations even before the ratification processes in national parliaments), and public opinion seems to be shifting further against free trade and free markets in general (at least in the EU). 
In addition, several political events in 2016 might further complicate the negotiations (UK Brexit campaign, US presidential elections). The next official negotiation round seems to be in February, let's see how the discussion develops until then. The topic I plan to focus on in the coming months are: 
the public opinion in the EU and USA (in respect to globalization, free market economy, deregulation, populism)
the presidential election in the US, 
the development of the EU in/out discussion/referendum in the UK

COMMENT:  If negotiations over market access in public procurement won't even begin until February, I can't see how the whole deal can be wrapped up in 10 months after that.  I'm headed deeper into negative territory.

Much to consider.... This is vast, complex, and contentious agreement that dwarfs others of its kind in its scope and reach. Some of the agreements aims are at odds with the current populist notions of much of the participating nations electorates. Populist apposition may conflate or confuse TPP and TTIP into an opposition to trade agreements in general. The current “vibe” against big institutions that is a result of the failed austerity reaction to 2008 may energize political and populist opposition. Given the time frame and the number of nations involved, there is a high probability of an  election process underway somewhere during negotiations. Being so broad in scope, the agreement may activate a much wider, more organized, and more powerful populist opposition than these types of agreements traditionally do. While “completed negotiations” is different than a ratified agreement, it will be the completed negotiations which activates opposition in advance of the ratification process. This will be one of the first, great agreements of the new social media age. Keeping the most delicate parts of negotiations “secret” in this age seems unlikely. The time frame is long enough for game changing political and economic events to occur with the large number of disparate polities acting as a multiplier in this regard. This agreement also depends in part on the success of a parallel agreement, the “TPP”, which is itself prey to all the pitfalls and delays of the TTIP. The issues of the TPP thus act as a “delay multiplier” for the TTIP. There is no compelling political or economic reason shared by all parties why the completion date should be etched in granite.  It is not unusual for agreements of this size and type to consistently push back completion dates.

The current backlash will delay TTIP, but I think after some renegotiation it will still be completed since it provides too many benefits for governments to just ignore it because some people are afraid. The question whether this will happen before 1 January 2017 is difficult, but I would say that since the negotiations were almost finished, making some adjustments to address current concerns of people should be feasible with more than year to go. There is of course a chance that the renegotiation will take much longer, and there is a minor chance that the agreement will be cancelled completely, but given the benefits and how far the TTIP negotiations already have come I believe it more likely than not that it will be completed before 1 January 2015.

Numerous factors contribute to the current pace of discussions, negotiations and stages of agreement despite calls from EU states to escalate the pace of TTIP interactions.  The 11th round is scheduled for mid October 2015.  No exchange of positions on 10 of 24 chapters of the TTIP, including no negotiations have been made by the US or EU.  The current US Commission Status Report indicate that all position papers from the EU have been sent to the US. France indicates that they have received any serious proposal from the US since 2013.  Current talks are described as 'mid game status.'   Missing chapters to the TTIP include regulatory cooperation on: chemicals, cosmetics, engineering, pesticides, information & communication technologies, energy and raw materials including intellectual property are not at the negotiation stage for the TTIP.  Several contributory factors that slow the pace of the current momentum on TTIP are: negotiations on TTP (US, Japan, South-Korea, Vietnam & SIngapore); agricultural tariffs are delayed in the US-Asian negotiations for TTP; negotiations held up include: market access for "trade in goods and customs duties," regulatory cooperation in "food safety & animal and plant health," draft agreements not presented to members of parliaments, member states of the EU or the US Commission's TTIP Advisory Board, including business groups and non-governmental groups. While there is partial political agreement legal frameworks for political agreements remain to be discussed on competition issues, textile sectors, public procurement and 'technical barriers to trade.  More important, with the pace toward the presidential primaries moving along as fast as the 2016 Presidential Election itself, short and longer term outcomes will undoubtedly impact what is presented, discussed, negotiated and agreed to regarding TTIP.  It seems highly likely that a legal framework for TTIP agreement (despite some political agreements currently assumed) is a longer term outcome than expected.
Too many sticking points that will be unlikely to be resolved given upcoming 2016 elections in member states.

Although it has not been officially announced that TTIP negotiations should resume Oct. 19-23 in Miami, all the talk through the media around the agreement may as well be a way to influence the other partner to make concessions in the coming negotiations. As regards France, its influence in EU decision making has been declining in recent years and the remarks of the French State Secretary for Foreign Trade are to be weighed in the context of the next French regional elections in December 2015. The French government and socialist party are really down in the polls and have to redeem themselves in the eye of the French public opinion. They try to show and get support from farmers as the latter feel threatened by an agreement such as TTIP. It is a part of a strategy to diminish the increasing influence of National Front in French politics.
Moreover, on one side, the EU could need the agreement to be completed before the end of 2016, should the "Brexit" take a more credible turn in the wake of the 2017 British referendum. Reaching an agreement on the TTIP would indeed prevent the UK to leave the EU and would probably be one of the best arguments against euro-skeptics in the UK. It would consequently help prevent a EU explosion. One should also remember that the EU constitution was adopted against the public opinion vote in referendums in some major European countries (France, Netherlands).
On the other side, President Barack Obama has been under repeated criticism from Republicans or even from Democrats for his erratic or unclear economic policy/program. It might be for him of importance to leave a trace of relevance in this area and a legacy which would include the creation of the world largest economic market.
All those elements if they come in conjunction could trigger the probabilities the whole way around in very short a time.

A European commissioner (De Gucht) has stated that TTIP should be a "living instrument" meaning he believes the treaty should never be finished but should adapt to changing conditions.  (You might ask if it is a treaty at all in this case.) TTIP will not be concluded in 2016 because of US presidential politics.  Once negotiations are concluded, the process would be for the US Senate to ratify the agreement.  President Obama will not have the political capital to push the agreement through the Republican-controlled Senate.  Whoever is elected in November 2016 will want to have their fingerprints on the agreement.  A new US President will not take office until late January 2017.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transatlantic_Trade_and_Investment_Partnership "The TTIP Agreement texts are being developed by 24 joint EU-US working groups, each considering a separate aspect of the agreement. Development typically progresses through a number of phases. Broad position papers are first exchanged, introducing each side's aims and ambitions for each aspect. These are followed by textual proposals from each side, accompanied (in areas such as tariffs, and market access) by each side's "initial offer." These negotiations and draft documents can evolve (change) through the various stages of their development. When both sides are ready, a consolidated text is prepared, with remaining differences for discussion expressed in square brackets. These texts are then provisionally closed topic by topic as a working consensus is reached. However the agreement is negotiated as a whole, so no topic's text is finalised until full consensus is reached." "The first round of negotiations took place from 7–12 July 2013 in Washington DC. . . ." 
There has been 10 rounds of negotiations thus far. "After a proposed draft was leaked in March 2014, the European Commission launched a public consultation on a limited set of clauses and in January 2015 published parts of an overview." "If an agreement is to be made, it is not expected to be finalized before 2016." Criticism & objections to the proposed agreement from NGOs and activists in center on:
1) "National sovereignty and investor-state dispute settlements (ISDS). . . 
Investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS) is an instrument that allows an investor to bring a case directly against the country hosting its investment, without the intervention of the government of the investor's country of origin. . . some states have become increasingly resistant to such clauses." ". . . a coalition of over 200 environmentalists, labor unions and consumer advocacy organizations on both sides of the Atlantic sent a letter to the USTR and European Commission are demanding the investor-state dispute settlement be dropped from the trade talks, claiming that ISDS was "a one-way street by which corporations can challenge government policies, but neither governments nor individuals are granted any comparable rights to hold corporations accountable". Some point out the "potential for abuse" that may be inherent in the trade agreement due to its clauses relating to investor protection." 2)  " . . .the planned foreign investor protection scheme within the treaty, similar to World Bank Group's International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID), would endanger the sovereignty of the signatory states by allowing for a small circle of legal experts sitting in a foreign court of arbitration an unprecedented power to interpret and void the signatory states' legislation." 3) EU issues include: " . . . greater access to the American public procurement market, retained bans on imports of genetically modified organisms (GMO) crops and hormone treated beef, and recognition of geographic trademarks on food products." 4)  US issues include:  ". . . greater access for American dairy and other agricultural products (including scientific studies as the only accepted criteria for SPS policies). . . . measures like the EU ban on hormone treated beef (based as they are on the precautionary principle) are not considered by the WTO to be based on scientific studies." 5) US also wants . . . " "tariff-free motor vehicle exports," and retained bans on foreign contractors in several areas," including domestic shipping (see Merchant Marine Act of 1920)." 6) "U.S. producers are concerned by EU proposals to restrict use of "particular designations" (also known as PDO or GI/geographical indications) that the EU considers location-specific, such as Feta and Parmesan cheeses and possibly Budweiser beer." 7) "At French insistence, trade in audio-visual services was excluded from the EU negotiating mandate." 8) "The European side has been pressing for the agreement to include a chapter on the regulation of financial services; but this is being resisted by the American side, which has recently passed the Dodd–Frank Act in this field." 9) "European negotiators are also pressing the United States to loosen its restrictions on the export of crude oil and natural gas, to help the EU reduce its dependence on energy from Russia." 10) "US negotiators put pressure on the EU over proposed pesticide criteria. A number of pesticides containing endocrine disrupting chemicals were in draft EU criteria to be banned. On the 2nd May 2013, US negotiators insisted the EU drop the criteria."  11)  "Bulgarian government announced that it will not ratify the agreement unless the United States lifted visa requirements for Bulgarian citizens." 12)  criticism is that " . . . "more than 93% of the Commission's meetings with stakeholders during the preparations of the negotiations were with big business"."

COMMENT:  Trade negotiations are like Hydra:  a many headed snake that grows new heads as soon as one is lopped off.  They take forever.  TPP negotiations have gotten bogged down.  The WTO TFA took nearly 20 years.  This question doesn't call for ratification by Congress:  just completion of negotiations, however, this is so complex and involves so many parties that I just don't see it happening within this time-frame.
GMOs, Investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS), and a few other issues I don't recall, will stymie this. How long? Just my first spitball.
Let me be the first to throw a dart.
By then we should have a new president and maybe a less fractious senate and congress.
